user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of process_param__all_cpus:
```c
static enum PerfRepl_param_result
process_param__all_cpus (const char *param_name)
{
  if (0 != tool_params.threads)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "Parameter '%s' cannot be used together "
             "with '-t' or '--threads'.\n", param_name);
    return PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR;
  }
  if (tool_params.thread_per_conn)
  {
    fprintf (stderr, "Parameter '%s' cannot be used together "
             "with '-P' or '--thread-per-conn'.\n", param_name);
    return PERF_RPL_PARAM_ERROR;
  }
  tool_params.all_cpus = ! 0;
  return '-' == param_name[1] ?
         PERF_RPL_PARAM_FULL_STR :PERF_RPL_PARAM_ONE_CHAR;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No code fragment in the provided function is provably unreachable. Each conditional (if (0 != tool_params.threads) and if (tool_params.thread_per_conn)) can legitimately evaluate to true or false at runtime, so both the bodies (with fprintf and return) and the subsequent fall-through path are potentially reachable. The final assignment (tool_params.all_cpus = ! 0;) and the return using the ternary expression are reachable when the earlier returns are not taken; both arms of the ternary depend on the runtime contents of param_name[1] and thus are potentially reachable. There are no labels, gotos, or code following an unconditional return that would be dead. Note: possible undefined behavior from dereferencing param_name[1] if param_name is too short is a correctness/robustness concern but does not constitute unreachable code, so it is not reported under Rule 2.1.
